It is hard to hire purely on merit.

That's why some companies practice blind hiring, testing candidates for jobs without knowing anything about them.
Noel King of NPR's Planet Money team found a company that took this to a new level.
Aline Lerner is one of the people at the forefront of the blind hiring movement in Silicon Valley.
She built an online platform called interviewing.io that lets companies interview job candidates anonymously.
Two people first meet in an online chat room.
The interviewer gives the candidate a test, like a math problem or a line of code to write.
But even if they're anonymous at the beginning, at some point, she says, they're going to have to talk.
One of the things that came up was if you can hear somebody's voice, it's going to be, in most cases, very easy to tell what their gender is.
So we were trying to think of how to get around that.
Lerner used to be a software engineer.
So this was a problem she could work with.
We've realized that we could actually modulate people's voices and their pitch in real time.
Disguise the voice so you can't tell if someone's male or female.
She built some software and started playing around with it.
